Posts.Content: Apr 19, 2013 12:43AM kathindc wrote: I was 61 at dx a year ago and was told I was stage 1a, grade 2, er+>90%/pr+>90%, HER2-, <1cm and no onco score. Â My surgeon recommended lumpectomy. Â After going through having another spot biopsied prior to surgery (the radiologist doing a stereotactic biopsy walked away from it because he didn't think he could get the tissue and I had to have it rescheduled as an MRI guided biopsy which gave me a three inch hematoma in my breast because of the failed try) and then seeing an oncologist a week and a half later who I found contrite and dismissive about side effects and seemed a tad upset that I would probably use the radiologist my husband used for his basal cell carcinoma, I had an epiphany moment. Â I wanted BMX with no reconstruction (I had been doing my research all along since dx). Â I fought my surgeon over sentinel node biopsy but finally went along with it. Â Turns out the hematoma blocked the dye, so he went to the node he felt was the sentinel. Â Node was negative. Tumor was taken on biopsy. Â DH asked if I needed to go through any other treatments and he said no. Â Canceled the follow-up appointment with the ONC although my surgeon felt I should have seen her but I told him I did tell them I changed my surgery and there was nothing there for them to work with. Â Both my surgeon and my GYN have told me I made a very good decision. Â I could not see myself ever being put through what I went through last year. Â Yes, I miss my breasts. Â Yes, even though I wanted the BMX I still can be emotional about it but as my surgeon said, "You lost two body parts. Â It's a normal reaction." Â Yes, I made a drastic choice, BUT I did not want to risk _any_ SEs that would affect my quality of health or life. Â I live flat and have never worn "foobs" and have no desire to wear them nor does my DH see the purpose for me to do so. Â  There is so much to take into consideration when making our decisions that at times it is overwhelming. Â Each choice is so individual to the person making it and is the right choice for them.

Posts.Content: Mar 3, 2013 04:32PM kathindc wrote: Talk about a stereotactic biopsy from hell. Â The tech had me on the table and I had a hard time getting in a comfortable position. Â I was as comfortable as possible when she had me go for a mammogram to make sure they were finding the right spot. Â Back to the table. Â Down went my breast. Â Got as comfortable as possible only to have me move some to get me positioned correctly. Â Plates came together on me. Â Had difficulty breathing due to my rib rubbing on the rise to the opening. Â Radiologist comes in and starts the procedure. Â After several tries, he stops and comes around to tell me he is stopping the procedure because he isn't sure he will be able to get the correct tissue and wants it done by MRI. Â Asked me if that was ok with me. Â I told him no but what was I suppose to do. Â He then walks out of the room. Â The procedure should have been an MRI guided biopsy all along. Â When it was done this way a week later, I ended up with a very large hematoma which caused a problem with the dye going to the sentinal node two and a half weeks later when I had my BMX. Â It is amazing what doctors will put you through. Â I found out later that he questioned himself about the biopsy being down as stereotactic since the mass was difficult to see in the mammograms but didn't want to question his colleague who recommended that it be done that way. Â It would have been nice if he had given me the courtesy of a conversation to discuss this instead of leaving me extremely upset and crying. Â If you need another one, see if they won't do it my MRI.
Posts.Title: Stereotactic Biopsy Irishwfl kathindc
